characters: AND THEN YOU DARE QUESTION ME
LAST TIME YOU SAW BIN LADEN
-- MAYA, JESSICA, AND OTHERS TOSSED TO THE GROUND, SOME

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I own you, Ammar. You belong to me. Look at me. This is DANIEL STANTON, the CIA's man in Islamabad - a bi American, late 30's, with a long, anarchical beard snakin down to his tattooed neck. He looks like a paramilitary hipster, a punk rocker with a Glock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explaining the rules) If you don't look at me when I talk to you, I hurt you. If you step off this mat, I hurt you. If you lie to me, I'm gonna hurt you. Now, Look at me. His prisoner, AMMAR, stands on a decaying gym mat, surrou by four GUARDS whose faces are covered in ski masks. Ammar looks down. Instantly: the guards rush Ammar, punch and kicking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me, Ammar. Notably, one of the GUARDS wearing a ski mask does not ta part in the beating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel and the masked figures emerge from the interrogati room into the light of day. They remove their masks and w see that one is a beautiful young woman in her mid-twenti She has a pale, milky innocence and bright blue eyes, thi and somewhat frail looking, yet possessing a steely core that we will come to realize is off-the-charts. This is MAYA, a CIA targeter and subject-matter expert on her fir overseas assignment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the guard) Are we gonna board up these windows or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just off the plane from Washington, you're rocking your best suit for your first interrogation, and then you get this guy. It's not always this intense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. She's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so you know, it's going to take awhile. He has to learn how helpless he is. Let's get a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we should go back in. Something about the strange intensity of her expression m Daniel reconsider and he turns back to the interrogation room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, there's no shame if you wanna watch from the monitor. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. At the door, Daniel hands the ski mask back to Maya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might want to put this on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not wearing one. Is he ever getting out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: Ammar, bruised from the beating, is restrained with ropes Maya stands a few feet behind Daniel, attentive, wary of what is to come. This is her first interrogation and she on the verge of vomiting from the stench in the room. She looks around at the sound-proofed walls, the puddles of w on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now, this is about you coming to terms with your situation. It's you and me, bro. I want you to understand that I know you, that I've been studying you for a very long time. I could have had you killed Karachi. But I let you live so you and I could talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You beat me when my hands are tied. I won't talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life isn't always fair, my friend. Did you really think that when we got you, I'd be a nice fucking guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a mid-level guy. You're a garbage man in a corporation. Why should I respect you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're a money man. A paperboy! Daniel paces around Ammar, anger rising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A disgrace to humanity!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your uncle murdered three thousand innocent people. I have your name on a five-thousand dollar transfer via Western Union to a 9/11 hijacker. He leans into Ammar's ear. Uncomfortably close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you got popped with 150 kilograms of high explosives in your house!

dialogues.speaker: AND THEN YOU DARE QUESTION ME
dialogues.text: And then Daniel smiles, laughs. Mercurial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just fucking with you. Beat. He laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about 9/11. What I want to focus on is the Saudi group. Daniel shows him a photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That there is Hazem al-Kashmiri. And I know this dude is up to some serious shit, and what I want from you is his Saudi email.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel free to jump in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ammar, bro, I know that you know this dude, just give me his email...and I will give you a blanket. I will give you a blanket and some solid food. No response from Ammar. Daniel starts putting on his glov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that you know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you before, I won't talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have it your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the masks) Let's go. It all happens in a flash: in one swift motion, Daniel pu Ammar to the floor, the guards pin his limbs, and Daniel smothers Ammar's face with a towel. Ammar thrashes. Daniel considers his next move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grab the bucket. Maya follows Daniel's gesture to the corner of the room, where there's an ICE CHEST filled with WATER and a PLASTI PITCHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put some water in it. She dips the pitcher in the water, hands shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, let's go. The stress and strain on her face is enormous as she brin the bucket back to Daniel. Daniel starts pouring the water on Ammar's face, which is now covered by a towel. Ammar thrashes with rising panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hazem was a friend of Ramzi Yousef, you guys met in Tunisia back in the 70s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasping for breath) I don't know, you asshole. Maya shakes her head "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not credible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a terrorist, that's why I'm doing it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Daniel pours water over the towel so it hits Ammar's nose

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want emails of the rest of the Saudi group. Give me emails of the rest of the Saudi group! Give me one email, and I will stop this! Ammar doesn't speak. He can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's in the Saudi group, and what's the target? Where was the last time you saw bin Laden? WHERE WAS THE

dialogues.speaker: LAST TIME YOU SAW BIN LADEN
dialogues.text: Daniel throws the pitcher, rips the rag off Ammar's mouth and water spurts out - Ammar nearly drowned. He gasps for air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what defeat looks like, bro. Your jihad is over. Daniel stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him up. The guards bring Ammar to his feet. Daniel, shifting his persona yet again, touches Ammar's f and speaks to him with the comforting tenor of a therapis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try to understand the concept here. I have time, you don't. I have other things to do, you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cool that you're strong. I respect it, I do. But in the end, everybody breaks, bro. It's biology. Dan and Maya exit. They've learned nothing.
A colorful, dusty city. Busy markets. Poor children. Dens traffic. Meanwhile, across town:

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DIPLOMATIC QUARTER
dialogues.text: National flags. Imposing buildings. Armed guards. The outpost of a superpower. Maya drives through the checkpoint and up to the main gat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Descending the lobby staircase with Daniel is JOSEPH BRAD Chief of Station, Pakistan, a smooth, vain, sophisticated former case officer who hasn't quite buffed all the blood out of his fingernails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did it go the other night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was good. The local cops need tactical help. But he's Tier fucking One, baby. There's your money maker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the guy that's KSM's nephew? What's his issue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's being a dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's trying to outsmart you, tell him about your PhD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going to have to turn up the heat. He needs to give us the Saudi group now. They reach the lobby, where they can see Maya sitting in holding area. They walk towards her as Bradley considers what Daniel is asking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gotta have that - given the family ties. Permission granted, Daniel reassures his boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight with his uncle, prints all over the 9/11 money. Daniel knocks on the glass for Maya to come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bradley, clocking her good looks) Was I lying or what? The guard opens the door and Maya comes through - not man females come through that door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya, this is Joseph Bradley, our illustrious station chief. (as they shake hands) Joe and I did Iraq together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we continue our Christian mission here. Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was your flight? They walk down the lobby towards the Secure Wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's been having a great time ever since she got in, isn't that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like Pakistan so far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's kinda fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You volunteered for this didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Bradley smiles. He knew she didn't volunteer. They reach a secure area and Bradley checks Maya through electronic door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third floor, northeast corner. She goes through and Daniel and Bradley watch her walk aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think she's a little young for the hard stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington says she's a killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children's crusade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want the next generation on the field. Listen, I have a meeting with ISI in twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're slow rolling us in Lahore - you might want to bitch about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see the cable from London?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude, I've been in a dark room with another man for the last two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya finds her desk. It's covered with grime. She tries t clean it as best she can, then sits and looks at the blan log-in screen of her computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of thirty-somethings filing in for a meeting, chatting, comradery, taking seats around a conference tab
We will get to know: JACK, mid-40s, a scruffy teddy bear, the liaison from the National Security Agency (NSA). JESSICA, 30s, an experienced targeter, and the only woman the station who wears a skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some dude tells the Malaysian station that his nephew works with a guy who knows a guy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on - He goes to a big feast in Bangkok about a year ago. The guest of honor? Usama bin Laden. Laughter in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I say, was Tupac there too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, but you forgot - you forgot Mullah Omar. J.J. and JEREMY, two case officers, continue the banter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is worth 5 million bucks. J.J. You know we're going to have to chase it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me, man. No job too small.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I have a gift for you, my friend. Jack hands Jeremy a piece of paper. Daniel and Maya enter a little late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone, this is Maya. Maya, everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't ask how it's going with Ammar because she's not going to fucking tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ammar is withholding? Daniel nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington assesses that Abu Faraj is officially our new number three - JESSICA moves to a wall chart of AQ leadership and reposi Abu Faraj's mugshot to number three in the line, two down from Usama bin Laden. Meanwhile, in the background, the riffs continue -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Best man for it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: London station is already asking if we think he's in contact with anyone in the U.K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like we're just keeping it from them. Jessica sits back down and gets down to business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jordanians are being really helpful with Ammar's transit papers. Jessica passes Daniel a file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any imminent threats in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want the Consulate, the Marriott, it's low security. And they've got Majid Kahn talking about gas stations in the US.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's a conversation? Jessica shrugs. At this point, she believes that it is me a conversation - not a fully realized plot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly? There are six hundred questions in there. I'd concentrate on Heathrow. The Saudis. Does it matter what Faraj thinks about Heathrow? How much latitude does he get to pick targets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he'll give up the Saudis. But Heathrow is gonna be tough. Anyway. Anything from last night? J.J. Quetta base thinks they have a bead on the Arabs that escaped, and they're going to meet with the ISI this afternoon, hopefully to set up a raid down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Lahore reporting ISI down there was painfully slow last night. Again. I'm beginning to think it's not incompetence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree, I spoke to the Chief about that. Anything on bin Laden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from a cable) A farmer on the Afghan border near Tora Bora reports: a diamond shaped pattern in the hills, tall male in the center of the diamond, flanked by four guards. It's consistent with UBL's movements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's supposed to be his royal guard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's pre-9/11 behavior. Jessica doesn't appreciate the challenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have reason to believe he's changed security tactics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We invaded Afghanistan. That's a reason. And so the rivalry begins. J.J. Hey, boss, I got a guy for five thousand bucks, he can set up a taxi stand and snoop around a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, don't need him, the diamond sighting is bullshit. See if the Paks will send someone to talk to the farmer. Anything else? We need to be putting runs on the board against Faraj. Speak to the case officers who didn't see fit to make it today. And thank them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The loud WAILING of the early morning call to prayer from the loudspeakers of a nearby mosque wakes Maya on the cou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel and the guards enter Ammar's cell with Maya. Danie switches on a floodlight, awakening Ammar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take it easy today, huh? Daniel hands Ammar a bottle of orange juice and a bag of falafel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry? The food in here sucks so I got you some of this. Ammar grabs the lunch sack and scarfs down the falafels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard Reid, wow. I was thinking about him. The guy gets a bomb in his shoe on a plane. Unbelievable. You know him, don't you? Slowly, Ammar nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you said that. I have an email from you to him. I've had all your coms for years, bro. Who else is in your Saudi group?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just handed out some cash for them. I didn't know who the guys were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you lie to me, I hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you. I do, I believe you. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want the water again, or do you want something else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just give me a name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Daniel kicks out the chair from under Ammar. The masked guards walk to the rope pulleys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see how this works? You don't mind if my female colleague sees your junk, do you? Daniel pulls down Ammar's pants. Maya flinches at the bar nakedness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude, you shit your pants.
Daniel turns to Maya -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay here, I'll be back. Daniel goes out, leaving Maya standing alone in front of naked, chained man. Ammar looks at her imploringly and she struggles to meet eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friend is an animal. Please, help me. Please. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can help yourself by being truthful. The door handle turns. It occurs to Maya that perhaps Dan was testing her resilience, too, as Daniel re-enters with DOG COLLAR in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a dog collar. Daniel unhooks Ammar, snaps the collar and leash around h neck, as Ammar cries out against the humiliation. Maya flinches. Daniel is relentless:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You determine how I treat you. Now Daniel drags Ammar on all fours, pulling him by the l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to walk you. Maya watches in horror as Daniel walks Ammar to a far cor of the room, then leans down to address his victim:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck do you think is going on, Ammar? Wahleed has already told me that you know. At last, Daniel reaches an area of the room where there i large wooden box resting on a platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This box sucks. I'm going to put you in it. Ammar tries to speak but can't get a word out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When is the attack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday? Sunday where? This Sunday or next Sunday? Ammar mumbles, almost inaudibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it Sunday or Monday? Ammar doesn't answer. The masked men approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which day is it? Partial information is treated as a lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saturday. Beat. The masked men open the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday! The guards grab Ammar and carry him to his wooden tomb. H shouts with his last reserve of energy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ammar, which day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday, Tuesday, Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thursday. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday. Daniel slams the box shut. Once again, he's learned nothi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU: a magazine CLICKS into the receiver of a black assau rifle. The weapon, carried by a BEARDED ARAB MAN dressed in stre clothes, rises to shoulder height.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - The man enters the hallway of the KHOBAR RESIDENTIAL TO - And immediately opens fire on TWO WESTERN MEN he happen to find inside, killing them both.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE OVER
dialogues.text: - The CRACK of the shots sends the rest of the residents into a panicky, screaming dash for cover - As he strides quickly down the hall, he finds three oth RESIDENTS scrambling for safety, and shoots and kills the all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU TV: news footage of the massacre. Daniel, Jessica, and Maya look on in defeat. The "Saudi" attack they tried to prevent by pressuring Ammar has occu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about the Saudis, they'll take care of business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You warned them - they didn't take you seriously - this is what happens. It's not on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said that? Zied? Fuck him. This is on me. Ammar is on me!! And it's on her!! (pointing to Maya) We can't let this be a win-win for AQ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no. You had - what - days - brief custody - and an unresponsive ally. The way you do this is you look ahead. London. Heathrow. Mass casualties. That plan is still active.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ammar doesn't have a clue about what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to be really careful with people in KSM's circle - they're devious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not going to talk about attacks on the homeland. He's going to withhold operational details on the KSM network and probably on bin Laden. (flipping her argument) But he's been in complete isolation, he doesn't know we failed. We can tell him anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bluff him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't slept, Dan. He's clueless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't remember, do you? You - me: same same. Bad memory. While GUARDS move in the deep b.g., Daniel and Maya are s at a picnic table with an appetizing spread of Arabic foo

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Short term memory loss is a side effect of sleep deprivation. It should come back to you. The Guards bring a prisoner to the table and remove his h Ammar. He stares weakly at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. How can I remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After we kept you awake for 96 hours, you gave us names of some of your brothers and saved the lives of a lot of innocent people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is the smart thing to do, you're starting to think for yourself. Ammar is lost. But the food is tempting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat up! You earned it. Ammar eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you flew via Amman to Kabul to hang out with your uncle? Mukhtar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you man, I know you. Alright, you got me - flight manifests. It must've been pretty fucked up for you guys after 9/11. What did you do after the invasion and before you went back to Pesh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After 9/11 I had to choose: fight, to protect our turf - or run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You chose to fight. Ammar looks Daniel right in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to kill Americans. We tried to get into Tora Bora but the bombing was too high. We couldn't cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, who is the "we" in that sentence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and some guys who were hanging around at that time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can eat with some other dude and hook you back up to the ceiling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamza Rabia, Khabab al-Masri, and Abu Ahmed. Maya makes notes on her pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Abu Ahmed? I've heard of the other guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a computer guy with us at the time. After Tora Bora, I went back to Pesh - as you know - and he went North, I think, to Kunar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his family name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abu Ahmed al-Kuwaiti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abu Ahmed means "father of Ahmed", it's a kunya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ammar, I know the difference between a war name and an Arabic name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got you there, dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to you both: I don't know his family name. I would have never asked him something like that. It's not how my uncle worked. My uncle told me he worked for bin Laden. I did see him, once, about a year ago, in Karachi. He read us all a letter from the Sheikh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did it say? Daniel offers Ammar a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarette? Ammar accepts. Daniel's lights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It said "Continue the jihad. The work will go on for a hundred years."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We fade into a dimly lit research room, where Maya is alo watching interrogation video recordings on an array of monitors. Some of the videos are rough; but most simply depict two people talking. The video she's watching now s a hooded prisoner sitting in a filthy room, the walls sme with red stains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and I are gonna talk about some of the guys in the training camps, yeah? The prisoner sits in a chair. He's hooded, but relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of these brothers have done some bad things, and what I want to do is I want to separate them from the people like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a guy called Abu Ahmed from Kuwait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I remember him. A nice guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How close was he? What was his relationship to the leadership?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he eat with you guys - did he eat with the good guys - or did he eat with the leadership?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, sir. I have no idea about things like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you do, you don't need an idea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya hits pause and we see that her desk is filled with o windows of interrogations: she is analyzing ten videos simultaneously, comparing them to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She plays another video showing a Turkish prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you met with Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, was this one of the facilitators? The Interrogator flashes a picture. The prisoner moans.

dialogues.speaker: TURKISH INTERROGATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is this Abu Ahmed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She fast forwards a video - shot in a Polish facility. Th prisoner appears to be cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KSM, your boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mukhtar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mukhtar,'potato', you say 'potahto'. I say 'fucking KSM', but yeah, 'Mukhtar.' After Mukhtar was captured, what did Abu Ahmed do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abu Ahmed, I believe he went to work for The Sheikh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya is still in the research room. She's been going at this for hours and looks fatigued. CU SCREEN: a different INTERROGATOR from the previous vid PRISONER is an older man chained to a desk. The exchange in Arabic with an English subtitle on the screen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Karachi, in 2003 or 2004.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was carrying a letter from bin Laden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still going, looking exhausted now, Maya manipulates the controls of yet another video clip with a different INTERROGATOR and PRISONER. We're now in a Moroccan facili The interrogator shows him a photograph of a bearded man. Henceforth, The Photograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abu Ahmed. The interrogator holds The Photograph right in front of t prisoner's face, allowing us to see it as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abu Ahmed. Abu Ahmed. Abu Ahmed. Freeze frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Yemeni prison - the dialogue is a mix of French and Eng

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abu Ahmed - is he the courier for bin Laden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows who works directly for bin Laden? Let's say he's part of the mix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were there other people who carried messages from bin Laden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many other people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four or five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's talk about them-- The image freezes. Maya stares at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya is in the kitchen grabbing something to eat. Jessica, the only other person working this late, walks i pours herself some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the needle in the haystack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Facilitators come and go, but one thing you can count on in life is that everyone wants money. The rivalry is in full bloom. Sometimes it's friendly. Sometimes it's not so friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're assuming that Al Qaeda members are motivated by financial rewards. They're radicals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct. You're assuming that greed won't override ideology in some of the weaker members.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money for walk-ins worked great in the cold war, I'll give you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just not sure those tactics are applicable to the Middle East.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya hastily throws her clothes and a wig into a suitcase the world's fastest packing job -

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: A sprawling shipyard in an industrial area. A large MILITARY FRIGATE sits in the harbor. A dark haire WOMAN and a MAN board the ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first we don't recognize the woman with heavy makeup walking down the narrow corridor, and then we realize it' Maya in disguise. She enters a vast cavernous hold accompanied by a middle aged Afghan man, thick shouldered with years of hard experience in his kind, somewhat sad eyes. This fatherly man is HAKIM, a former political prisoner i Afghanistan and one of the CIA's most important assets. In the galley, a PRISONER is chained to a table. Hakim sl him The Photograph. The prisoner speaks in Arabic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he looks like Abu Ahmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did he work for? Hakim translates. Then the prisoner speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was mostly with Abu Faraj - they were always together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he do for Faraj?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carried messages from Faraj to bin Laden and from bin Laden back to Faraj. Maya leans into Hakim -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to ask him something to see if he's telling the truth. We don't know if he really knew Faraj. Hakim speaks to the prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just told me the names of all of Faraj's children. I think he's telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya is pitching Bradley in his office. Bradley sits with his feet up on his desk, holding The Photograph. Daniel is slouched on the couch in back. Jessica is perched on the arm of the couch, bare legs cro Bradley notices. Maya stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty detainees recognize that photo of Abu Ahmed. They say he's part of the inner circle of guys who were hanging out in Afghanistan pre-9/11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of them say that after 9/11, he went to work for KSM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When KSM got captured, he went to work for Abu Faraj, primarily as a courier from Faraj to bin Laden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's good. You still-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we don't know if Abu is on the outside of the network - part of a series of cutouts and dead drops - or if he has a direct connection to bin Laden. Does bin Laden invite him into the living room and hand him a letter directly? Or is Abu just the last guy in a long line of couriers, so that's why everybody knows him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not all you don't know. You don't have his true name, and you don't have a clue of where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know that he's important. The fact that everybody's heard of Abu Ahmed but nobody will tell me where he is suggests that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. Detainees could withhold his location for any number of reasons. Perhaps they don't know; perhaps this Abu is just a cover story and he's really a fucking unicorn. The withholding doesn't reveal what you want it to - does it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you did find him, you don't know that he'd be with bin Laden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know what we don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a tautology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to Maya) Listen, not one single detainee has said that he's located with the big guy, just that he delivers messages. Am I wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's still good work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me know when you've got some actionable intelligence, preferably something that leads to a strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city is in full swing on this bright mid-summer morni CARS and BUSES roll through the crowded streets.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE OVER
dialogues.text: Passengers inside the bus read newspapers, listen to musi another ordinary day. Then, the bus explodes!

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: File footage of the aftermath:

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: This is what remains of the #10 bus, which was traveling through Tavistock Square...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joseph Bradley sits at his desk. The weight of the world his shoulders. On the television in the background, the news report continues, showing disaster footage of PEOPLE bloodied, screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war on terror is growing and spreading, like an octop throughout the base. We trace the new tentacles of the CI facility - more hangars, vehicles, PEOPLE moving to and f

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: All around, groups of Londoners are standing on corners asking themselves

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: what has happened here, and who could possibly have done this? We find Daniel trying to catch a moment of solitude...eat an ice cream cone and standing in front of a makeshift ca filled with wild MONKEYS. The monkeys are watching Daniel intently, their hands gri the wire cage. Daniel playfully feeds them some of his ic cream. A CIA GUARD approaches Daniel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the monkeys) You Agency guys are twisted. The detainee is ready. Daniel nods, weary. Then a monkey reaches through the bar and steals the remainder of Daniel's ice cream cone. He looks at the monkey and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain pelts the brown city, turning the gutter water black

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to understand that I know you. I have been following you and studying you for a long time. I chased you in Lahore. We find Maya entering the gates of a Pakistani prison. Th weather makes the place seem especially bleak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HASSAN GHUL, Al Qaeda financier, sits manacled to a desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had you picked up instead of killing you because you're not a violent man and you don't deserve to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you do have deep ties to Al Qaeda that I want to ask you about before you get sent to your next location, which might be Israel. Ghul looks ashen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However, depending on how candid you are today, I may be able to keep you in Pakistan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to ask you a series of questions based on your knowledge of Al Qaeda and your position as key financier for the organization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have dealt with the mukhabarat, I have no wish to be tortured again. Ask me a question, I can answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can you tell me about Atiyah Abd al-Rahman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He works for Zawahiri. He's in charge of military tactics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what context have you ever heard the name Abu Ahmed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He works for Faraj and bin Laden. He is his most trusted courier. Maya works hard to hide how pleased she is to have this confirmation. She's not entirely successful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brought me many messages from the Sheikh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you last see him, and where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will never find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even I couldn't find him. He always contacted me out of the blue. He is one of the disappeared ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pakistani families enjoy a fine summer day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BOMB is being strapped to a MAN'S leg by a PAKISTANI POLICEMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how this works? The man is terrified.

dialogues.speaker: PAKISTANI POLICEMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just act naturally. The Policeman finishes securing the bomb, and sends the m out the door (who we will later deduce is Abu Faraj's courier).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faraj's Courier walks past playing children... while from nearby tower, Daniel observes. After a moment, ABU FARAJ, who we recognize from his photograph, appears at the south end of the park. Faraj walks in the direction of his courier, noting his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHILDREN playing. Several people in BLACK BURKHAS.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHT SUN.
dialogues.text: At last Faraj reaches an open area where he can see his courier face to face. They exchange a nervous glance that conveys the danger: I a trap. Faraj spins to flee, but it's too late. The black BURKHAS descend on him. It turns out they are heavily armed Pakistani agents. From on high, Daniel watc his captured prey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel and an armed guard escort a hooded and handcuffed Faraj to his cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you like? Bob Marley? Reggae? Egyptian music? Just let me know, if there's music you like, I can make a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel and the guards take Faraj to a cell laced with bar wire and lock him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I be honest with you? I'm bad news. I'm not your friend. I'm not gonna help you. I'm gonna break you. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done it before. (Faraj dozes, weak) Hey, wake up. You haven't eaten in 18 hours, we've got to keep your energy up. You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guards force feed Faraj through a feeding tube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley approaches Maya at her cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in luck, I got you a one-on- one with Faraj.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously? Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't thank me until you hear what I want for it. He drops a folder on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to take care of all of this before your favorite subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to see what's in the folder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want family ties, financial networks, media sources, disgruntled employees, imminent threats, homeland plots,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foreign cells, health status, trade craft, recruiting tactics -- anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Maya and Faraj look tired. This has been going on fo hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of brothers told us Abu Ahmed was bin Laden's courier and that he worked very closely with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're thinking of Abu Khalid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al Buluchi. My courier for the Sheikh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so you're telling me that all the other brothers are wrong, and there's some famous Buluchi guy that is working for you and bin Laden that I've never even heard of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should you have heard of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does this Buluchi guy look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tall, long white beard, thin. He uses a cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of like Gandolf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was the last time you saw him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A month ago, in Karachi, but I don't know where he is now. Sometimes I wouldn't even see him, he would just tell me where to leave the messages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you. The GUARD in the room with them leans forward and SLAPS F across the face. Faraj's expression doesn't change and Maya herself remain flat and steady, unmoved by the violence. She's not quite the same young lady she was a few years a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not being fulsome in your replies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't force me to tell you something I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do realize this is not a normal prison. You determine how you are treated, and your life will be very uncomfortable until you give me information I need. The guard slaps Faraj again. Faraj is impassive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya looks on impassively as Faraj is subjected to harsh treatment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya is retching in the stall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya walks around the facility, quiet at this hour, and f another insomniac, Daniel, by the monkey cage. The cage i empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faraj is completely denying knowing Abu Ahmed, and that's using every measure we have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's either going to withhold or die from the pressure you're putting on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to take a run at him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Since when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I've been meaning to tell you: I'm getting outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I've just seen too many guys naked. It's gotta be over a hundred at this point. I need to go do something normal for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to Washington, do the dance, see how that environment works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should come with me. Be my number two. You're looking a little strung out yourself. Maya looks at Dan. No longer the man he once was. She doesn't hide her disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to find Abu Ahmed from D.C. They both look at the empty cage, clocking the irony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They killed my monkeys. Something about an escape. Can you fucking believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Maya, you gotta be really careful with detainees now. The politics are changing and you don't want to be the last one holding a dog collar when the oversight committee comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And watch your back when you get back to Pakistan. Everyone knows you there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in Pakistan, the country has indeed changed to a mor militarized police state, and as we establish the new environment, we find Maya's grey sedan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up to a checkpoint manned by PAKISTANI POLI The Policeman look at the car - look at the plate - the p is diplomatic - they walk around the car and stop at the window - shine their bright light right into Maya's eyes. A POLICEMAN motions for her to roll down her window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the Marriott. I assume you noticed the dip plates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have a bag - The policeman motions to a DUFFEL BAG resting on the rear seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a gym bag. Maya does not get out of the car. She stares at him defiantly. He advances forward a bit. She rolls up her window, flicks the door lock, and starts dialing her cell phone. The policeman walks away to rejoin his group. The police confer. The original policeman returns, this time with several other cops. They knock on the glass. Hard. Maya stares straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica is waiting at the table in a beautifully appointe room.
Maya walks in, flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking checkpoints. Maya sits down, absorbed in her Blackberry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're socializing. Be social. Maya puts away her blackberry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I know Abu Ahmed is your baby, but it's time to cut the umbilical cord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Faraj went south on you - it happens. There are still cells in London and Spain planning the next round of attacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can work on it at the same time - plus I think it's a good thing that he lied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not at the expense of protecting the homeland, you can't. Wait a minute, why is it a good thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound just like Bradley. He doesn't believe in my lead either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good thing because the fact that Faraj withheld on Abu Ahmed is revealing. The only other thing he lied about was the location of bin Laden himself. That means Faraj thinks Abu Ahmed in as important to protect as bin Laden. That confirms my lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or it's confirmation bias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all just worried about you, okay? Is that okay to say? Maya rubs her eyes, not liking where the conversation is going. She forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's probably stuck in some check- point somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two hooked up yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, I work with him. I'm not that girl, that fucks. It's unbecoming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? A little foolin' around wouldn't hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So no boyfriend. Do you have any friends at all? She doesn't. Jessica's phone rings -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey - that's okay - SUDDENLY, AN EXPLOSION RIPS THROUGH THE RESTAURANT.

dialogues.speaker: --SMOKE FILLS THE ROOM
dialogues.text: As alarms wail, Maya struggles to her feet, grabs Jessica the arm, and they stumble to safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toward the destroyed kitchen, helping each other over obstacles, twisted metal, gaps in the concrete, etc, past injured workers and burning flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue moving through the debris as the smoke intensifies. They find each other's hands and grab tightly.

dialogues.speaker: C.U.
dialogues.text: The destroyed Marriott.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: The blast left a crater 10 meters wide in front of the hotel. The Marriott, one of the most popular destinations for locals and Westerners...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're high above the wild hinterlands of the Hindu Kush, gliding over the rocky slopes and the pine forests.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: We move from peak to peak until we find a remote valley, we zoom down... and nestled in the valley we can just mak out the barest outlines of a tiny village of mud huts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we are inside a hut and we've shifted to the perspect of a hand held camera, as if someone inside this stone ag interior is filming on our behalf, and we see a hard floo thin gaps in the walls, and FIVE TRIBAL ELDERS talking casually, eating and drinking tea.
We pan across the weathered faces, long beards, and see a video recorder resting on a ledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica strides excitedly, almost breaking into a run, th the warren of cubicles that lead to Maya's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica beaming as she approaches Maya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jords have a mole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Jessica pops a CD into Maya's computer, loads a file that plays the same video clip we have just seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made this video to prove his bona fides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up! The camera stops on one man, BALAWI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humam Khalil al-Balawi, he's a Jordanian doctor. He's really motivated. Maya practically bolts out of her chair. Together, they start walking towards Bradley's office -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could be it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley has just finished watching the video. Maya and Jessica are in his office waiting for his verdict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right there in the inner circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't buy it. Didn't you tell me yourself nobody turns on Al Qaeda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jords worked him for a year. Dinners, money. They've convinced him that it's his patriotic duty to turn on Al Qaeda and get rich doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, so the Jords say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. We can't rely on the Jords. We have to evaluate him face to face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He may not be that smart. He may be full of shit - but we have to talk to him to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The key is to meet him so we can figure out for ourselves what he can actually do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He really asked for a dialysis machine? You can fill the damn thing with poison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya and a few analysts are watching TV - President-elect Obama is being interviewed on 60 Minutes when Jessica com into the room with disappointing news -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The meeting with Balawi is off. He can't come here to Islamabad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't or won't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not going to travel - security

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV interview with Obama reaches the subject of enhanc interrogation, and the women pause to listen to the Presi elect declare, "America does not torture." Then they continue:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants us to go to him. He'll meet in Miram Sha or the tribals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows we're white. You'll get kidnapped up there. DAVID, an analyst, adds his two cents to the conversation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could do it somewhere else - Germany, or the UK? He's got a clean passport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not going to travel out of Al Qaeda territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're not going to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not. Believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're stuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Camp Chapman? Afghanistan. That could be safe territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We survey the sprawling base from above.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: Helicopters and Humvees traverse the base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica applies icing to a birthday cake as she cradles a SATELLITE PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This may be going overboard, but I baked him a cake! MAYA O.S. Muslim's don't celebrate with cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so literal. Everyone likes cake. It's not too late for you to come, you know. It will be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya sits in front of a series of monitors. She watches a live Predator feed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be a straphangar. It's your show. You were the first to see the potential in this.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Come on! We've got lots of wine! The target on Maya's monitor disappears in a puff of smok

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool. Bring me back a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica pours two glasses of wine and raises a toast to h colleague, JOHN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to get technical, but this guy is actually the first big break we've had since 9/11. To big breaks and the little people that make them happen. Clink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far, everything he's said we've cross checked and it's proved legit... and I think the money is persuasive. 25 million dollars?! That buys a new life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he might be exaggerating his access?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possibly. But Al Qaeda needs doctors and they are short staffed and that could explain his rise. In six months to a year, if he doesn't fuck up, he could be called in to treat bin Laden. And at that moment, with 25 mil on the table, I think he gives up the Big Man. And if he doesn't, we kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same gathering as the day before, waiting under the merciless sun.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: Jessica turns to her crew, which includes LAUREN, a young operative, ZIED, a Jordanian intelligence agent, and the base's CIA SECURITY GUARD, among others. They rehearse th impending meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So John? (John turns to her) When he arrives, I'll set the tone, and then I'll flip it to you - and you'll talk about asset protection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Lauren, I know you want to get some questions in there - but give Balawi time after John speaks. We'll cover the basics and have his birthday cake, then we'll get to the nitty gritty.
Jessica turns to Zied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that order okay, or do you want to introduce everyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll introduce you, and you introduce your team. He knows this is a high level meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick question: all is taking place inside our main building?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. And Lauren? Washington will want real time updates so please stay on top of that. Be concise. The Director is in the loop. And I wouldn't be surprised if he doesn't update the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm on it. They take in the possibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I just need to get Balawi's ass down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting and waiting. No cars approach. The sun beats down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several hundred yards before the Camp entrance is a beat- SEDAN. The car pulls up to the checkpoint but doesn't proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Security Gyard) Why are there gate guards there? We talked about this, no one is supposed to be there when my source arrives. You might have spooked him already!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Procedures only work if we follow them every time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time is different - I'm sorry I can't explain, but it's for a good cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm responsible for everyone's safety, okay? It's not just about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just need them to go away for a minute. You can search him as soon as he gets here. The Security Guard pauses, then into his radio:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All stations, go ahead and stand down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guards move away from their post. The sedan drives pa the gate into a maze of barriers. We follow the car as it navigates the maze of HESCO barriers, kicking up a cloud dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica runs back to her team and flashes a thumbs up. She smiles and pulls out her phone, sending a text.

dialogues.speaker: ECU
dialogues.text: He's here. Brb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool! The car navigates the second set of barriers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya types on her computer: Wassup you talking yet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica looks up to see the car approaching and puts the phone back in her pocket. The sedan is now 50 yards away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, he's coming. We're gonna search him when he gets here. Everyone prepares. The car gets closer and closer, a driv in front and a passenger in back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya texts again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer when you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sedan pulls to a stop. A BLACKWATER GUARD taps on the backseat window. Balawi exits on the passenger side. His free hand is in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the other guard) Is he supposed to limp like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your hand out of your pocket! Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his M4) Get you hand out of your pocket!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allahu Akbar. Jessica's smile fades And Balawi detonates a suicide vest hidden under this jac and the resulting shrapnel storm pulps the crowd, massacr them all -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya looks at her computer screen. She sees her last inst message..And waits for a response. Beat. Maya looks up, concern on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The explosion smoke still hovers over Camp Chapman. News reporting of the attack plays over the horrific image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya huddles on the floor under the corner of her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office has thinned out, and most people have gone hom for the day. Maya is crouched in the corner. A wounded animal. Jeremy, the case officer from the conference room approaches and gives Maya a computer disc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay? No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think this day could get any worse, but bad news from Saudi intelligence. The courier guy, Abu Ahmed, is dead. It's a detainee video. Maya still fighting to contain her grief, takes the file an almost welcome distraction. She puts the disc into her computer and hits play. CU COMPUTER SCREEN: A PRISONER being interviewed by a CIA CASE OFFICER holds the photo of Abu Ahmed we've seen so m times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead, in Afghanistan, 2001. I buried him with my own hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kabul. Maya stares at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Maya, I always liked this lead. Jeremy leaves Maya at her computer. She continues to stare at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya is still by herself. Her friend Jack approaches -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Sorry, I just got here. What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to smoke everybody involved in this op, and then I'm going to kill bin Laden. Off the darkness in her eyes we -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff has gathered to hear a word from the boss in a large conference room; it's packed shoulder to shoulder w dozens of people, including Maya, Jim, Jack, Hakim, and Bradley at the front. GEORGE WRIGHT, Chief of the Afghanistan Pakistan Departme has just flown in from D.C. A big man, striding quickly i the room with the street roll of the Bronx projects he gr up in, George looks ready for a brawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to make something absolutely clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you thought there was some secret cell somewhere working Al Qaeda, I want you to know that you're wrong. This is it. There's no working group coming to the rescue. He stares at his staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nobody else, hidden away on some other floor. There is just us. And we are failing. We're spending billions of dollars. People are dying. We're still no closer to defeating our enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They attacked us on land in 98, by sea in 2000, and from the air in 2001. They murdered three thousand of our citizens in cold blood, and they've slaughtered our forward deployed. And what the fuck have we done about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have we done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have twenty leadership names and we've only eliminated four of them. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want targets! Do your fucking jobs, bring me people to kill!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office has grown bigger and busier and the cubicle ma is filled with many new faces of young agents excited to in Pakistan. Sitting alone at her desk we find Maya just as she's fini a report. She gets up, crosses the room and goes to the desk of a young woman who reminds us in her idealistic enthusiasm of the way Maya was six years ago. This is DEB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I painstakingly combed through everything in the system and found this.
She hands Maya a file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him. He was one of ten names on a watch list sent to us by the Moroccans after 9/11: Ibrahim Sayeed. They told us to watch out for him, apparently they think his whole family and extended family is bad and has ties to KSM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was picked up for fake papers and a doctored exit visa leaving Afghanistan, traveling through Morocco en route to Kuwait. Abu Ahmed al- Kuwaiti. This must be Abu Ahmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter, but I wish I had that five years ago. How come I never saw it before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody saw it, most likely. There was a lot of white noise after 9/11, countries wanting to help out, we got millions of tips and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things got lost in the shuffle. Human error. Maya turns her attention back to the WHITE BOARD and as D keeps talking we follow Maya's gaze across the row of MUG SHOTS of Al Qaeda personnel. While a few of the men are African or are distinctive looking for other reasons, mos of them look fairly similar in that they're all wearing t same type of clothes and have the same trademark long gna beards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway I thought you should know about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to say I've heard a lot about you. You inspired me to come to Pakistan. Maya's eyes narrow. She keeps looking at the WHITE BOARD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you'll let me buy you a kabob sometime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't eat out. It's too dangerous. Maya stares at the Al Quaeda mugshots - a thought crosses her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya on the speaker phone to Daniel. We intercut. Daniel is now a suit in Langley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan, Debbie found Abu Ahmed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was in the files this whole time. The family name is Sayeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, but he's dead. So doesn't that make him a little less interesting to you? MAYA O.S. He may not be. We now know that Abu Ahmed is one of eight brothers. All the brothers in the family look alike. Three of them went to Afghanistan. Isn't it possible that when the three eldest brothers grew beards in Afghanistan, they started to look alike? I think the one calling himself Abu Ahmed is still alive. The picture we've been using is wrong. It's of his older brother, Habeeb. He's the one that's is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, what are you basing this on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have no intercepts about Abu Ahmed dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just have a detainee who buried somebody who looked like Abu Ahmed. But if somebody as important as Abu Ahmed had died, they'd be talking about it online in chat rooms all over the place. Plus, the detainee said that Habeeb died in 2001. We know that Abu Ahmed was alive then, trying to get into Tora Bora with Ammar. That means it's probably one of the other brothers that's dead. DANIEL O.S. In other words, you want it to be true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I fucking want it to be true. Maya slams the desk. DANIEL O.S. Calm down. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am calm. DANIEL O.S. State your request.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move heaven and earth and bring me this fucking Sayeed family's phone number.

dialogues.speaker: LANGLEY, VA.
dialogues.text: A dark (window shades down) executive office, where in th shadows a white American man in a nice suit is kneeling o prayer rug and saying the Islamic daily prayers. Daniel waits as the man recites the prayers and presses h pale forehead to the carpet. This is WOLF. He is the head of the agency's COUNTER TERRORISM CENTER (George's boss).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As-Salamu alaykum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alaykum salam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a couple hundred thousand. Four max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you gonna get that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could crack open the facilitator Maya's been looking for by giving us a phone number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's your killer, Wolf. You put her on the field. (reciting a phrase from the KORAN, in Arabic, then loosely

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allah rewards those who strive and fight over those that sit behind a desk. WOLF nods. If the blatant attempt to play on his Muslim belief bothers him, he doesn't show it at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you know, Abu Ghraib and Gitmo fucked us. The detainee program is now fly paper. We got senators jumping out of our asses, and the Director is very concerned. They will not stop until they have a body. There it is. The quid pro quo. There's a reason he's call The Wolf. Daniel considers all that he'll go through if he voluntee to be the fall guy for the controversial program.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ran it. I'll defend it.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: Daniel and a KUWAITI BUSINESS MAN in a suit are drinking ogling the RUSSIAN GIRLS prowling the place. After a few sips of his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to be back in Kuwait. It's good to see you again, it's been awhile. The businessman doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we're friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say we are friends. How come you only call me when you need help? But when I need something - you are too busy to pick up the phone. I don't think we are friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough. How about a V10 Lamborghini? How's that for friendship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wait while a Lamborghini SALESMAN, disheveled, clear just awakened, unlocks the door of the dealership.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Kuwaiti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poor fucker had to get out of bed. (to the Salesman) As-salamu alaykum. Thanks my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step inside and the salesman flicks on the lights revealing shiny cars displayed like jewels on rotating
platforms. While the Kuwaiti businessman peers inside a silver model, Daniel confers with the salesman like he's bought twenty of these cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a Balboni? Fuck me. This is nice. What are you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll choose this one. The salesman retreats to a back office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a nice choice, my friend. Daniel gives the Kuwaiti a slip of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think? The guy's a terrorist. His mother lives here. I just need her phone number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There will be no repercussions in Kuwait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody might die at some point in Pakistan. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound graphs of phone calls fill the screen. We cruise through rows upon rows of server facilities, a single mon in front traces a call to Rawalpindi, Pakistan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya chews on a peanut butter & jelly sandwich. Jack her on her cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not gonna like this, he's on the phone, but there's no team to deploy right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck. She dashes out runs down the hall to an Exit sign - burst through the door to a staircase -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Flies down the staircase - down to another floor, barge through the door -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station's surveillance team leader, LARRY, unstraps h flack vest. He looks like the kind of guy you don't mess with....so of course Maya barges into his space like a locomotive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you haven't deployed a team to stay in Rawalpindi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For one thing, it's dangerous. For another, the area is too congested for us to be effective without some predictive intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why you should forward deploy - so you can shorten your response time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, it wouldn't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy never stays on the phone long enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't tried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't have the personnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it is, my guys don't get any sleep tracking the threats within Pakistan. Larry pushes past her to leave, and she follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, I understand. But I don't really care if your guys get sleep or not. Maya looks at Larry's team sleeping on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conversation continues in the bar, for Maya has not relented, although the tone is softer now. She offers Lar a beer. He takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy you're obsessed with, what's his name again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abu Ahmed al Kuwaiti is the nom de guerre. His true name, we think, is Ibraheem Sayeed. His family lives in Kuwait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't it, like, eight brothers - and a million cousins - that we know about - anyone could be calling home -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - It's not like he's saying, "Hey mom, it's me, the terrorist."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the course of two months, he's called home from six different pay phones, from two different cities, never using the same phone twice. And when his mother asked him where he was, he lied. He said that he was in a place in the country with bad cell reception -- implying he was in the Tribals -- but he was in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a market in Peshawar. I'm sorry, but that's not normal guy behavior. That's tradecraft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he just doesn't like his mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if he talks about an operation, or refers to anything remotely fishy, I'll get on him. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not okay. Look, Abu Ahmed is too smart to tip his hand by talking about ops on the phone: he works for bin Laden. The guys that talk about ops on the phone don't get that job. Larry looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of my friends have died trying to do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe I was spared so I could finish the job. The girl is a true believer - as pure as they come. Larry looks at her. Her sincerity is persuasive. And just like that, he decides to help her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hakim walks through a crowded call center. Larry joins hi from a back entrance. They look around: nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hakim parks in front of the Rawal Call Center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The call center is arranged into two rows of cubby-holes, each separated by a privacy wall. Hakim searches the plac finds nothing.
